LANGUAGE: Welcome back to the Soviet Union
English: comrade Grigory Lemontov. You have been kept from your home country for far too long.

LANGUAGE: Your unlawful imprisonment by the capitalists of the west has finally come to an end. We are honoured to be able to welcome you back
English: comrade.

LANGUAGE: Three cheers for the return of Grigory Lemontov to his motherland!

English: hip!
comrades. Thank you.
please
Czech: follow me to my car
Comment: comrade. I'll take you to your tent.

LANGUAGE: It's truly an honour to welcome you back
English: comrade Lemontov. My name is Stanislav Shaposhnikov and I was responsible for the exchange.

LANGUAGE: Those three were western spies captured in Moscow. We reached a deal wherein you would be exchanged for them.
To Severovodsk. You'll have your accommodations there.

English: it felt like you were welcoming a hero.
were't we? To those that remember you
Czech: you are a great commander. To those new
Comment: you are a legend.

English: I don't feel like either. Is that Arzapol we're driving through? Did nobody bother to repair any of the destroyed buildings?

LANGUAGE: We never received the budget. And honestly
English: it reminds men of our defeat and motivates them to get better.

LANGUAGE: I was gone for seven years and Kolguyev still looks exactly the same.
The island itself has not changed. Other things have. You'll see that soon enough for yourself.
Stanislav Shaposhnikov... the name rings a bell
English: we must have met. Were you under Livanokh?

LANGUAGE: You could say that. I was under Rashiv.

English: I remember you...
let us not discuss it here. We shall talk in Severovodsk.

LANGUAGE: This tent has been assigned to you. Mine is just around the corner. We can talk freely here.

English: I remember. How did you survive?

LANGUAGE: Those blokes you left me with wanted to hang me from a tree. Before they could agree on which one
English: an American commando showed up and captured us. I spent the rest of the war imprisoned.

LANGUAGE: The fate of my comrades and Rashiv I only learned later. Nobody else from my group survived. You made sure of that.

English: not a day goes by when I don't regret what I did.

LANGUAGE: Remorse is a common feeling for those sentenced behind bars. It does not wash away your guilt
English: however.

LANGUAGE: I'm not asking for forgiveness. At the time
English: I did what I perceived as right
Czech: as necessary for the better of my country
Comment: my people. I was wrong but I can't take it back.

LANGUAGE: I won't judge you for your past actions
English: I leave that to God. I already came to terms with what occured. It is nothing we can change
Czech: unlike the future.

LANGUAGE: After the war I learned about you and Livanokh. How the Americans raided the villa and captured you while killing Livanokh. That's the official version of events.
Most people don't have a rason not to believe it
English: but I'm not among them. I met with George Dyaconsen and he was not the kind of man to shoot first and ask questions later.

LANGUAGE: You were Livanokh's loyal dog. If there was a fatality during the raid
English: it would have been you
Czech: as you would defend him to the last breath
Comment: am I not right?

LANGUAGE: Spit it out then. What do you think happened?
Do you really wish me to say it aloud? I think you killed Livanokh.

English: what does it make me?
of course. That's what I would tell you. Livanokh had to be stopped. If you ever wondered whether you've done the right thing
Czech: you have.

English: that is not the generally accepted opinion among our comrades. You should know that the Army general in charge of Kolguyev is Vladimir Volkov.

LANGUAGE: I remember him. A low lanking officer
English: loyal and smart.
he climbed high and now controls considerable armies and wields substantial political influence. Not enough to cause trouble yet
Czech: but enough to be of concern.

English: I only know he is still loyal to Livanokh and what was he trying to achieve. He might be continuing in his legacy.

LANGUAGE: I did not stop one madman to let another finish his job. Does he possess nuclear weapons?

English: thank god. But you do know the significance of Malden and what could that mean.

LANGUAGE: Does he wish to invade it?
I don't know. It seems like it
English: as we are concentrating more and more forces on Kolguyev. Slowly still
Czech: but surely.

LANGUAGE: What's the situation back at home?
Not good. A general political instability
English: seceding states
Czech: army mutinies
Comment: the whole mess that is Afghanistan... It's much different than what you remember.

LANGUAGE: This sounds serious. Can I count on you?
It is strange to hear you say that
English: Lemontov
Czech: but yes. I'll never forget Rashiv
Comment: but his is what he was fighting against. He would want us to finish the fight.

English: thank you
Czech: Stanislav. First and foremost
Comment: I need information. I have seven year long window I need to fill. I also need to meet the local commanders and get to know them to get a bigger picture of the situation.

English: you're right. Volkov is coming in tomorrow so we have time until then. He also ordered a uniform to be made for you
Czech: so he wants you back in the army. As long as he doesn't know the whole truth
Comment: he does not have a reason to go after you.

LANGUAGE: We keep the truth for ourselves.

English: let's see... there are five important people you should meet.
you need to meet Zubarev
Czech: the commander-in-chief. He is in charge when Volkov is not here. He is more of a politic than a soldier and I have my doubts about his capabilities
Comment: but he's very close to Volkov. Be careful around him.

English: there's Kaplinsky
Czech: the commander of Spetsnaz. You'll probably have to spend a lot of time with him very soon. I don't know much about him.

English: Frolov
Czech: the tank commander
Comment: you are already familiar with him. He hasn't changed much since your time.

English: the newcomer
Czech: Syomin. From what I've heard
Comment: a brilliant ace pilot and the commander of the air force. Apparently
column5: he has a family history of piloting. Don't let him start talking about that
column6: you'll never hear the end of it.

English: the logistics officer
Czech: Chernikov. Sometimes
Comment: he's hard to find
column5: just keep looking. He is in charge of all supplies.

English: If you wish to hear more about the events you missed
Czech: I can recommend two other people.

LANGUAGE: For domestic politics and the general world affairs
English: you can go to the postmaster
Czech: Boris Belsky. Every piece of paper
Comment: fax or telegram goes through him. He is also able to get his hands on some foreign journals
column5: so he knows a lot about the wider world.

English: you should go to Maksim Kuznetsov. Supposedly
Czech: he's been here from the very start. He's from logistics and knows everyone in the army. A good man to meet regardless.

LANGUAGE: You can take my car if you wish. Once you are done
English: get back to me. I'll be in my tent waiting for you.

LANGUAGE: Grigory Lemontov in the flesh. I almost didn't believe it when they said you'd be coming back.

English: I presume.

LANGUAGE: You presume right. You should know I was against the exchange. We lost three valuable spies.
It's one way to look at it.
I don't really see any benefit you are supposed to bring us. While you're here
English: you could at the very least tell me about Livanokh. You were there with him during the final moments
Czech: weren't you?

LANGUAGE: I would rather tell that personally to comrade Volkov
English: when he arrives.
of course
Czech: he should be the first to know. Tell me about the prison then.

LANGUAGE: It was long and solitary. Nothing of any interest.
What about the enemy? Any information or news?
You haven't seen anything or heard anything?

English: I was in prison.
I see. Never mind. Have you talked with Kaplinsky yet?
then you know you shall be leading Spetsnaz again.

LANGUAGE: Y - It didn't sound like I was given a choice.
Y - What would you possibly do instead? Get back to the mainland to lead a civil life?
N - You should. He has information regarding your future in the army.
N - Do you mean I cannot just pack my things and go back to the mainland to lead a civil life?
Don't be ridiculous. I've read your files. You've been soldier your whole life. You wouldn't abandon the army now when it most needs you.
Don't you feel any resentment to the Americans? They killed your brother Livanokh before your eyes. Or did the prison time break your will?
It's been ten years since I've been back in Russia
English: comrade Zubarev. That is all.
comrade Lemontov
Czech: do not worry about that. But there is still work to be done before that can happen.

LANGUAGE: That's something we can agree on.

English: it is very good to finally meet you. We never had the pleasure - Valentin Syomin
Czech: commander of the air force.

LANGUAGE: We had not. The pleasure is all mine.
Your imprisonment was very unfortunate. I've heard of your deeds and I am glad you are able to join us again.
The legendary Grigory Lemontov. Our paths have finally crossed. Captain Kaplinsky
English: at your service.
comrade Kaplinsky. Are you the new commander of Spetsnaz?
comrade Lemontov
Czech: but not for long now that you are here. We're already getting you your uniform and equipment. You shall be back in the field in no time.

LANGUAGE: What do you have in mind?
You are probably a little rusted after seven years of prison. The boys are ready to train with you and help you get back in to shape.
Once we are done with the training
English: comrade Volkov is going to assign us our next assignment.

LANGUAGE: If my eyes do not deceive me
English: I see comrade Lemontov. It's good to have you back
Czech: comrade.

English: good to see you. How are you?
same old. I am still the commander of our armoured forces
Czech: though there are not really any forces to speak of.

LANGUAGE: I long for the old days. We waged a hard war
English: but it carried meaning. It felt like we were achieving something
Czech: something nobody dared before us.

LANGUAGE: What happened with you after I was captured?
I was with comrade Volkov. We retreated with him to the mainland. Not everyone was so lucky.
When we got the island back
English: I returned here. Nowadays
Czech: I hadly ever go back to the mainland. I like it here.

LANGUAGE: It's calm and quiet most of the time
English: though the weather got even more cold
Czech: if you can believe it! But I am not giving up my sunglasses!

English: Lemontov!

LANGUAGE: You said you don't go back home anymore?

English: I don't really have a reason to. My wife died five years ago. Cancer.

LANGUAGE: We lived separately the last few years
English: but it still hurt. Without her
Czech: there is no real reason to go back.

LANGUAGE: The last time I was in Russia
English: it was at her funeral. I never looked back ever since.

LANGUAGE: What's the current situation with the tanks?

English: that's the main issue. Very little heavy tanks and modest amount of light tanks and transports.

LANGUAGE: We are able to support infantry to a limited extent
English: but in a tank battle we would not stand a chance.

LANGUAGE: We have been getting more stuff in lately
English: though we are still far away from a battle ready state.

LANGUAGE: What is the main tank model?
Still the good old T80 with slight modifications. There is no new design in the works anyway. You can't improve what is already perfect.
Can't argue with that. Any new recruits?
A good amount. I train them personally. It's a hard training
English: but if they can master the local terrain
Czech: they can fight anywhere.

English: they can't stay here
Czech: so we swap them around during the year.

LANGUAGE: It was good to see you again
English: comrade Frolov. Goodbye.
comrade Lemontov.

LANGUAGE: In person. What can I do for you
English: comrade?

LANGUAGE: I'm looking for information about politics and world affairs in the last seven years.

English: oddly specific
Czech: but I can oblige. What do you wish to know about?

LANGUAGE: Not good. The economy is stagnating
English: the political elite is corrupt and the socialist states and members of Warsaw pact are playing with the idea of secession.

LANGUAGE: There were a few in the last seven years. Comrade Brezhnev died in 1982
English: afterwards it was comrade Andropov
Czech: but he only lasted to 1984. Then there was a troika of comrades Ustinov
Comment: Gromyko and Chernenko. Comrade Ustinov died in 1985 and was replaced by comrade Mazurov. That's the current troika in power.

LANGUAGE: None of them have enough individual strength to rule alone and so they depend on each other. At the same time
English: they try to weaken the others so that they can gain an absolute power. The result is an ineffective rule and a lot squabbling.

LANGUAGE: I do not know how to fix the economy
English: but a draining war in Afghanistan and massive military spending do not help.

LANGUAGE: The seceding states is antoher matter. There were few demonstrations already in Poland
English: Czechoslovakia
Czech: Hungary
Comment: the Baltic states... The presence of the army restored order
column5: but tension is in the air.

LANGUAGE: There will have to be a change in the next years
English: the situation is not maintainable. What this change is going to look like and whether it can be peaceful
Czech: I can't tell you. One thing is certain - hard times are ahead.

LANGUAGE: How does the west look like?
The United States is as strong as ever. Although in recession for the first few years of the decade
English: now their economy is on sharp rise.

LANGUAGE: Ronald Reagan is the incumbent president since 1981. He took a hard stance against us - calling us an 'evil empire' and increasing the material support to our enemies.
They know we're in trouble and we cannot sustain the status quo for much longer. They will win in the long run without firinng a single shot.
I keep hearing about Afghanistan. The war there is still ongoing?
It was supposed to be a one year affair at the longest. Now it has become a seven year ordeal with no end in sight.
Although we captured all of the urban areas and the main roads
English: the mujahideen retreated to the mountains and waged a guerilla war. They received a substantial aid from abroad and the mountains provided them with cover.

LANGUAGE: We never managed to defeat them
English: it was impossible. Even leveling entire villages with helicopters did not diminish them. And so the war continued.

LANGUAGE: The was's been in a stalemate for years now. We spent a lot to achieve very little. I'm not sure what the current goal is
English: but even if we by some miracle managed to win
Czech: it would not have been worth it.

English: I needed that.

LANGUAGE: No problem. Were you living under the rock for the past seven years of what?
You could say that. I just returned from captivity.

English: you are Grigory Lemontov. They told me you'd be returning today. It was a pleasure
Czech: comrade! If you ever need any sort of information
Comment: I am your man!

LANGUAGE: That is good to know. Take care
English: comrade Belsky.
comrade Lemontov!

LANGUAGE: The hero has returned! I salute you
English: comrade Lemontov.
you haven't changed much. Still not an officer?

LANGUAGE: I am not suited to command people
English: comrade. I wouldn't take it seriously enough. I am much happier with my current position.

LANGUAGE: By your current position you mean the one you've kept for what
English: ten years?

LANGUAGE: My experinece only makes be better. So I am both happy and good at my job
English: a win-win situation. Did you come to hear about what's been going on around here?

LANGUAGE: Tell me about the end of the war
English: about the peace treaty.
they smashed the rest of our army. Some managed to retreat from the island
Czech: but many were taken prisoner. Not to mention all the equipment and vehicles.

LANGUAGE: In the end we managed to negotiate a somewhat favorable peace deal. We had to renounce our claims on Everon and reduce the Kolguyev garrison to one hundred men. In exchange
English: we received most of our prisoners back
Czech: with the exception of you. They also kept our equipment.

LANGUAGE: Everon was declared netural and the Americans also left it and returned to Malden. The peace treaty forbids us to attack Everon or Malden
English: otherwise hostilities will resume.

LANGUAGE: And that is the status quo.

English: Everon regained its independence. They tried to establish a democracy
Czech: but it wasn't easy. The rebel commander
Comment: Gaston Astier
column5: had a sizeable following as well as number of armed men at his disposal. The first few months
column7: they had to check with Gaston first. It felt like a military dictatorship in the making.

English: he made a deal with Astier - he named him the commander of the militias
Czech: granting him official power over the military
Comment: in exchange for not getting involved in the politics from there on. It worked well for years.

English: there had been some trouble. The police chief
Czech: Daladier
Comment: will run for president in the next elections in a few months. Petain is getting old and he might not get the support he once enjoyed. If Daladier wins
column5: Astier will not like it - he might get involved in politics again.

LANGUAGE: Police chief and militia commander - two armed institutions against each other - it might even boil over into a civil war. The next presidential elections will be very interesting and their outcome might shape the future of Everon for years to come.
Do we know anything about Malden?
Still an American stronghold. Their main training camp
English: heavily fortified and guarded. We don't know much beyond that.
comrade Kuznetsov
Czech: it was helpful.

English: you can always count on me! And let me tell you - I missed you! Goodbye
Czech: comrade Lemontov!

English: comrade Kuznetsov.
